I have already said that crossed callosal tract 
commences to be visible in perpendicular sections 
opposite the anterior margin of the genu of the 
corpus callosum. Further forwards than this 
the definition of the crossed callosal fibres becomes 
more & more indistinct <s>indefinite <\s> on perpendicular sections.
In horizontal sections, however, it can be seen 
that the same set of fibres arches <s>far<\s> forwards 
far in front of this. <s>end <\s> The fibres come across <s>out of <\s>
the corpus callosum from the opposite side & 
turn round to enter the <u>tractus medius <\u> & <u>externus <\u>;
And these fibres wh: pursue this course are chiefly 
derived from the under surface of the frontal lobe.
They are seen <s>slan <\s> in horizontal sections slanting 
forwards & upwards in the corpus callosum to 
reach the opposite side. They then arch forwards 
curve outwards & backwards, &, as before said,
enter the external & middle tracts. So that here 
although the fibres of the <u>crossed callosal tract <\u> do not arch so highly up as 
a little further back yet the same arrangement 
prevails, namely, that the fibres from the under 
surface of the <s>opposite <\s> frontal lobe of one side 
cross in the corpus callosum enter the <u>tractus 
medius <\u> & <u>externus <\u>, & by them are conducted back 
as we shall see to the basal ganglia.
I have already referred to certain obliquely cut 
fibres seen in the perpendicular <s>ly cut <\s> section
